name: Woman in Nature Poster
description: [ONLY 5 REMAINING] I knew this guy, he once said all female art is derivative of the vagina. It was supposed to be a dumb comment, but regardless, it turned into a tongue-in-cheek study for a series of the woman in nature. Looking at colloquial terms for female genitalia, which seem to be predominately nature-based, I illustrated them in their 'natural' form. 3 colour Risograph print. Signed A3. Limited to 20 copies. For more images, check out the HALLOO BLOG

name: #2 - The House of Horror
description: [ONLY 4 REMAINING] In the beginning of the age of mass production, 1862, Henry Cole (founder of the V&A museum) held a rebellious exhibition - The Chamber of Horrors. Dismayed at the poor manufacturing and design quality of Victorian goods, he curated a show that exposed and dissected the poor workmanship, hideous form and garish design now synonymous with Victorian taste. His friend, Henry Morely, visited and was inspired to write a satirical essay on the mental degradation of a neurotic man forced to live in a house filled with these manufactured 'horrors'. Funny and beautifully observed, still relevant to any suffering designer, the essay is accompanied with an introduction to the historical contexts of the piece, and side notes throughout. For more pics, visit HALLOO's zine blog

name: #1 - The Offline Other
description: [ONLY 4 REMAINING] HALLOO's first zine is a sum of parts from all over the world. Designed in Melbourne, HALLOO worked with UK writer Dean Brown, on his essay The Offline Other, and the Laptopograms of Italian creative Aditya Mandayam. Written as a criticism of our growing reliance and familiarity of social networking, Brown writes as an outsider, seeking the answers of our dependency and is prophetical of the future. Together with Mandayam's imagery - photographs printed from the light exposure of a laptop screen - the zine is a reflective artifact of 2011. For more pics, go to HALLOO's zine blog
